. This is how the title
appears in B, except that  (which is absent in T) is
apparently from a later hand. Plato probably called the dialogue  (compare the titles ,  etc.
the majority of the dialogues are named after an interlocutor):
the words  and  were added by Thrasylus,
whose date is about the Christian era. The  is the
sole example of an endeictic dialogue: it is so called because
it was thought to be an arraignment () of the Sophists.
That this is the meaning of , and not probative,
can be inferred from the fact that Albinus used 
in its place (, ch. v. Cobet
takes the right view: see his edition of Diog. Laert. III. 51). The
arrangement of the Platonic dialogues into tetralogies is also
probably due to Thrasylus. The  is the second
dialogue of the sixth tetralogy, the others being (1) 
(3)  (4)  See Grote's  1, 158 ff.

p.#text:
38. . Callias, son of Hipponicus,
belonged to one of the richest families in Athens (below, ). His
devotion to the Sophists in general is remarked upon in
  (cf. ): but he seems to
have been particularly attached to the doctrines of Protagoras:
see   (i.e. ) . One
of his two sons (), Protarchus, appears as an interlocutor in the  In 393-392 Callias was associated with
Iphicrates in the command of the Athenian forces at Corinth,
and as late as 371 we find him acting as ambassador to Sparta
(Xen.  VI. 4). It appears that he spent all his money and
died in actual want (Athenaeus, XII. 52).

39. . The MSS. have : probably
the archetype had , by a natural mistake. Cobet rejects
, reading , on the ground that with 
the Greek idiom does not repeat the verb: but there is no proof
that the verb could not be expressed with  (without ).

title: Hippias Maior
Philosophie der Griechen,
p.#text:
61. . Hippias of Elis was one of the most accomplished andif we may trust the Platonic writingsostentatious
of the Sophists. According to the  (285B ff.) he
claimed to be at home in all the learning of the dayin Astronomy,
Geometry, Arithmetic, Philology, Music, Mythology, History
and Archaeology. See Zeller's  I, 956 ff.

Charm.

p.#text:
62. . Contrast 
. Either construction is admissible. Prodicus
of Ceos is repeatedly mentioned in the Platonic writings. A
fellow-citizen of the poet Simonides (below, , he professed
like Gorgias and Hippias to educate young men (,

 127E, ) and received very large sums in
return for his instruction together with the gratitude of his
pupils. On one occasion, when in charge of a political mission
from Ceos, he is said to have won great reputation in the 
at Athens for his conduct of public business, and to have given
at the same time private lectures, which were popular and well
paid ( 282C). He laid great stress on the importance of using words in their correct sense ():
see below,   and ,  163D, 
197D; cf. also ; but this was only taught (we are
told) in his 50-drachma lecture; the impecunious Socrates had
only paid one drachma and was not quite master of this subject
(). Socrates is fond of professing himself a pupil of
Prodicus, e.g. below,  ,  163D. Prodicus
wrote eulogies of Heracles and others (): the
substance, if not the actual words, of his Apologue of Heracles at
the cross-roads is given by Xenophon,  II. 1. 21. A scholiast
on  says the Athenians put him to death by hemlock
for corrupting the youth, but there is no other authority for this
unlikely story. Cf. Zeller, I, 952 ff.

Charm.

p.#text:
23. . The mother of Xanthippus and
Paralus had once been the wife of Hipponicus, to whom she bare
Callias: Plut.  XXIV. 9. In as well as in 
Plato remarks that Pericles was unable to teach the art of
statesmanship to either of his two sons: cf.  118E . They both died of the plague.
One of the most interesting fragments of Protagoras describes
the fortitude of Pericles when his sons died: see Appendix 11,
p. 221, Frag. 3. Charmides, son of the elder Glaucon, was
Plato's maternal uncle: the dialogue  is named after
him. He was  ( 155A), and
as remarkable for  as for personal beauty (
157D). He was afterwards one of the Ten, and fell along with
Critias at the battle of Munychia in 404 B.C. (Xen.  II. 4. 19).
Of Philippides and his father Philomelus and Antimoerus of
Mende (on the west coast of the peninsula Pallene) nothing
further is known.

Aristotle,  IV. 4, p. 1014. 32 ff. . Thus (among others) Heraclitus,
Anaxagoras, and Empedocles called their books ,
i.e. on the substance which gives birth () to all else. By
Plato's time the word had acquired a wider meaning equivalent
to de rerum natura, our Nature, and it is in this sense that

21. . It is at the poet Agathon's house that the
scene of the  is laid. From his speech in that dialogue
194D ff. we should infer that he had studied under Prodicus to
some purpose. Born about 447 B.C., Agathon was first successful
on the tragic stage at an early age: cf.   (sc.
) . He visited the court of
Archelaus about 407 B.C. and died probably about 400. That he
was held in esteem by the Athenians appears from . . For  cf. 
193B.

p.title: Hell.
p.#text:
23. . Adimantus son of Cepis is not elsewhere
named. The son of Leucolophidas was afterwards 
under Alcibiades, whose policy he supported (Xen.  I. 4.
21): he was taken prisoner at the battle of Aegospotami, but
spared by the Spartans. He was afterwards put on his trial by
Conon on the charge, not improbably a true one, of having
betrayed the Athenian fleet at this battle: see Kock on .

div1.head: CHAPTER VIII
p:
After Hippocrates has been introduced to Protagoras, the latter
enlarges upon the antiquity of his profession. At the suggestion
of Socrates a circle is formed to hear the Sophists discourse.

21. . An obscure sculptor (not painter) of this
name is mentioned in  No. 1229 (quoted by
Overbeck,  p. 300). The Zeuxippus here mentioned is supposed to be the same as the famous painter Zeuxis
of Heraclea (the Greek colony in Italy, most probably) who is
mentioned by Plato in , and several times by Xenophon ( I. 4. 3,  10. 1,  4. 63 ): see Overbeck, pp. 311 ff. Zeuxis began to rise into fame
probably about 424 B.C.: he would therefore be still a young
man about the date when this dialogue is supposed to take
place: see Introduction, p. xxxiii. Brunn would read 
for  here, but according to Fick (quoted by Sauppe)
 is nothing but a familiar diminutive of : for
other similar examples see Fick,  pp. xxviii ff.  in proper names was aristocratic
() and could upon occasion be omitted or added
without prejudice to personal identity: cf.   with  1071 ,
where  adds mock dignity to .

53.   and its
derivatives are often used of sophistic professions.

Socrates professes to disbelieve that  can be communicated
by teaching. His arguments are twofold: (1) while in matters
connected with the arts of building, ship-carpentry, and the like,
the Athenians will listen only to the professional man, in politics
they give ear to any and every one: (2) Athenian statesmen have
not been able to communicate their political virtue to their sons.

Protagoras' reply falls into three sections, viz. (1) 
(2)  (3)  cf. Introduction, pp. x-xi. In the
first he is concerned to justify the Athenians for allowing
everyone to address them on political questions: this he does in
the first instance by relating a myth of prehistoric man.

title: Mem.
Polit.
p.#text:
It is probable that this myth comes from Protagoras' treatise
, mentioned in Diog. Laert. IX. 55.
It does not resemble the other myths of Plato in point of style,
and if not actually written by Protagoras, it is at least carefully
modelled on his way of writing: cf. the similar imitations of the
style of Agathon in  ff. and of Prodicus below,
337 A ff. See Introduction, p. xix. That the Sophists taught by
means of parables we can see from Prodicus' Apologue of
Heracles in Xen.  II. 1. 21 ff. The other passages in Plato
treating of the primitive constitution of man are  269C ff.,
 ff. and  ff. In  ff. there are
also some points of resemblance to the present story.

For air and water is substituted here . Fire is the rarest and earth the densest of the four
elements: Protagoras' theory is that air and water are produced
by mixing these in different proportions, for  cannot
mean merely that the elements interchange. Cf. the theory
attributed by Aristotle to Parmenides:  I. 5. 986. 33 

. It is noteworthy that Plato himself regards all
four elements as differentiated, although imperfectly, before the
creation of the  by the : cf.  ff. The
chiasmus in  followed by  is part of
Protagoras' art.

Protagoras now passes to the second part of his reply (24D), in which he seeks to prove by two arguments that men
believe that virtue can be taught: (1) as we hold men responsible
for , it is clear that we conceive of it as capable of being
acquired (; (2) punishment is in point of fact
intended to teach well-doing (.

allowed that his  are hardly consistent with themselves.

personal beauty, stature and health. Schanz's rejection of  is therefore needless.

pronoun merely as anticipating , then the statement
becomes too wide: for not all , not all  (, on this view), come to men , as indeed the next

25.  Plato's own theory of punishment so far agrees with this, but goes deeper: see  ff.
. Vice (being ignorance) is disease of soul, as  is of body:
it is the business of the judge to cure the one as of the physician
to cure the other: cf. -B and  

:
hence ( 480B ff.) the sinner should go before the judge as
readily as the patient to a doctor, and should even accuse his
friends. In the ideal city the judges are to put to death incurable
sinners just as the doctors will allow incurable patients to die:
 ff. . The same holds good of punishment after death: for Ardiaeus and the others in ,
whose punishment is everlasting (),
are incurablethe majority are punished to purge them of the
guilt contracted upon earth and teach them to choose more
wisely their lot of life next time. The remedial view of punishment is embedded in the genius of the Greek language, as is
shown by the punitive sense of .
The older and sterner view () appears more
rarely in Plato's time.

45.  should be understood of tracing (by dots or otherwise) the outlines of the lines
() which form letters. These outlines would be filled up
by the pupil: see Blmner, 
p. 315. The usual view (since Heindorf) has been to regard the
 as horizontal lines ruled for guidance; ut pueri in
schola directe s. ad lineam scribere iubentur, ita in vita quae
agunt ad legis normam iis dirigenda sunt (Kroschel). Such a
view is, however, inconsistent with the meaning of 
and of , and (in view of Plato's statements as to the
nature of Law) renders the simile inexact.  in Plato
regularly refers to an outline drawing (as  to
moulding in outline ) and is opposed to 
and (in Aristotle) to , e.g. -D , and , where a litigant's  is
called a sort of outline drawing ,
but which his speech must simply  is
similarly used, only with the added idea of guiding: e.g. 
III. 403D-E  and  . The point of the simile is this. As the child draws
his pen between the outlines of the lines forming letters

(making e.g.  into ), so we must keep our actions
between certain outlines, which are the laws. Plato invariably
regards  as only , within which our actions should fall:
cf.   (whence 
here and in ): see also  294A ff. for which reason in the
 (VI. 497D) there must always be a power above the
laws. The explanation which we have given does not disagree
with the account of Seneca in his  XV. 2. 51 Pueri ad
praescriptum discunt. Digiti illorum tenentur et aliena manu
 ducuntur: it is supported by Quintilian,
I. 1. 27 cum vero iam ductus sequi coeperit, non inutile erit eas
(sc. literas) tabellae quam optime insculpi, ut  ducatur stilus. It is probable that both these authors had
the present passage in view.

div1.head: CHAPTER XVII
p:
Here begins Socrates' criticism of Protagoras' speech. The
question is first raisedIs Virtue one, or many? The connection
between this question and the speech of Protagoras is that if
Virtue has a unity in knowledge, it is teachable, otherwise not:
see Introduction, p. xviii.

to the syntax are twofold: (1)  with the optative in protasis;
(2)  (in clauses of this kind) with its verb expressed. Cases
of the potential optative in the protasis are given by Goodwin,
 p. 192 (e.g. Xen.  I. 5. 3 ):
for  with verb expressed Heindorf cites   () . Socrates'  (hardly
serious) in is not inconsistent with , since he
at once qualifies his assent by : it is
sufficiently represented here by . We therefore
agree with Heindorf, Wayte, and Turner in retaining the MSS.
reading: other editors mostly read either , or drop  and retain .

33. :  and  are looked on as
two  virtues.
34. :  cf. and E.

Socrates elicits from Protagoras (1) that while Virtue as a whole
is one, the single virtues differ from each other and from the
whole like the parts of the face, that it is possible to possess one
virtue without possessing all, and that in all there are five
virtues, justice, temperance, holiness, bravery, wisdom, of
which the last is greatest (; (2) that the virtues
differ from each other not only in themselves, but in their
 (; (3) that justice is just, and holiness holy
(. The refutation of Protagoras does not begin till
the next chapter.

 (l. 17) the contrary and the contradictory are confused, as is frequently the case in Plato's dialogues: see note on

at a friend's misfortune because envy of a friend's success
implies joy at his ill-luck (cf.  50A), and

the rules of logic in this matter (see -202A), but the
tendency of Greek thought and life was not to rest content with
negations; whence words like  acquired a
positive significance, and Solon could enact (
ch. 8 ) . Part of
the argument in the next chapter suffers from the same flaw:

div1.head: CHAPTER XX
p:
Without establishing more surely the identity of justice and holiness, Socrates now seeks to prove the identity of temperance
and wisdom, and begins to discuss the relation between temperance and justice.

p.#text:
The proof that temperance and wisdom are the same is briefly
as follows:  is the opposite of , and also of
: but a thing can have but one opposite: therefore
 and  are identical. It is admitted at once that
 and  are opposites: the proof that  is
 is of some length and (as well as the assertion
that a thing can have but one opposite) assumes the identity of
the contrary and contradictory. The usual sense of 
(intellectual folly) and the meaning natural from its derivation
(as the opposite of ) are alsoas is natural to one who

. The nausea is of course that felt
by a sick person at the smell of food: so far there is therefore no
reason for holding  to be corrupt and reading  (as
Kroschel formerly read), still less  with Bergk. But it is
not clear how oil could thus prevent nausea, nor does there
seem to be any parallel among the ancients to such a statement.
It is known that the ancients (like many modern peoples) used
oil in cooking much as we use butter (see Blmner's  p. 228), but the present passage seems rather to
point to the use of some kind of fragrant oil sprinkled on the
food after it was cooked. The Greeks were at all events not unfamiliar with the use of scents in banqueting: see Xen. 

II. 2 ff. Kroschel thinks Plato is making fun of Protagoras by
putting into his mouth the word  pro  vel ,
but this view will hardly command assent.

div1.head: CHAPTER XXII
p:
This and the next three chapters form a kind of interlude. In
this chapter Socrates, protesting against Protagoras' long replies,
remembers an engagement and is about to go, and Callias
beseeches him to stay.

45. . The ordinary clothing of an Athenian consisted of a , or shirt, with a  or short mantle worn
above it. The  was a short cloak of coarse material worn
by the Spartans and sometimes by the Laconisers in other
states to take the place of both  and . It was the
ordinary garment of Socrates (), and was afterwards
much affected by the more ascetic philosophers, such as the
Cynics (Diog. Laert. VI. I. 13). Its use was supposed to be a
mark of sturdy simplicity and austerity of manners.

52. . The original meaning of the word 

was love of knowledge for its own sake, no particular
kind of knowledge being specified. The verb  is first
found in  . In the present passage (as in Thuc. II. 40 ) the word retains its original wider meaning, viz, love of knowledge in general; but side by side with
this in Plato it has the more restricted meaning of Philosophy,
e.g.  . The wider meaning is also found in
Aristotle, where he calls Theology the Highest Study (), and elsewhere.

frequently appears attributed to different sophists or their
representatives in the Platonic dialogues: the historical Hippias
was a leading champion of  (see Introduction p. XX).
Usually, however,  is represented as a convention binding
men together into friendship and  (whose teaching is that
might is right) as responsible for the enmity of man to man in
the savage state: e.g.  ff.,  ff. From the
natural principle of Like to like is here deduced something
like the Stoic doctrine of the kinship between wise men.

div1.head: CHAPTER XXV
p:
Socrates protests against appointing an umpire, and in order
that the conversation may go on is willing that Protagoras should
become the interrogator. The others assent, Protagoras
reluctantly.

div1.head: CHAPTER XXVI
p:
Here begins an episode (lasting down to the end of ch. XXXII), in
which Protagoras cross-examines Socrates upon a poem of
Simonides. For the bearing of this episode on the general
subject of the dialogue see Introduction, pp. xxiii ff.: and for the
different restorations of the poem Appendix I.

3.   is verses. As education in
poetry formed part of the usual curriculum at Athens, it was
natural for the Sophists to pose as poetical critics, and Sauppe
gives a number of references to show that they did so: it will
suffice to quote Isocrates,  18 : cf. below  where Hippias says he
has a speech ready on the poem, and  ff. . Protagoras appears as a critic of poetry
in , p. 1456. 15 ff. (where he censures Homer  ) and in  14, p. 173. 19 ff. The popularity of such discussions as the
present may be inferred from the well-known scene between
Euripides and Aeschylus in the  1119 ff.

. The Scopadae were a ruling family at Crannon and
Pharsalus in Thessaly. Simonides seems to have frequently been
their guest, and wrote poems in their honour: the most famous
is that referred to by Cicero,  II.  352-3.

12.  is here more than morally good: it includes bodily
and external as well as internal well-being: whence  as well as : see also note on  l. 4 below. The notion
of external well-being belonged to the word from very early
times: see Grote, III, 45, n. 3: good and bad are applied in
Theognis and Solon to wealth as contrasted with poverty
nobility with low birthstrength with weaknessconservative
and oligarchical politics as opposed to innovation. This sense
survived in classical times in the political meaning of , e.g. Xen.  II. 3. 12, Pl. .

58.   is of will,  of

note on  and cf. Cope on Ar.  II. 19. 9. Prodicus
does not touch on this example in his speech in 337, but it is
quite in Plato's way to select a fresh example (cf. 
147A-B, 166E by the side of 159C, 169A-B), which may in this
case be supposed to come from Prodicus' lectures (cf. .
We should expect the article to be repeated with , as
the two words are to be distinguished (cf. below in l. 63 ); but the article is sometimes dropped with
the second of two words even when the words are contrasted,
e.g.  . Here the effect of its omission
is perhaps to suggest that the two notions are after all more like
than different.

63. . The distinction though long ago recognised by the philosophers was not always present in ordinary
speech: otherwise (as Kroschel points out) Protagoras' censure
of Simonides would be too absurd, and Socrates' pretended
bewilderment out of place. But that Simonides in this poem
drew a distinction between  and  is certain: whether
it was the same distinction as Socrates himself draws later is
another question; see on  in

Prodicus and  (. At the same time Protagoras
might fairly turn Socrates' fallacies (see on  against himself and say that if Simonides said it was not difficult to be
virtuous, he meant that it was easy to be so.

div1.head: CHAPTER XXVIII
p:
Socrates introduces his exposition of the poem with a paradoxical theory that Sparta is the oldest home of philosophers.
The wise men of old accordingly expressed their wisdom in
pithy Laconic sayings, and such a saying is that of Pittacus.
Simonides, as a rival craftsman, wrote this entire poem to overthrow that saying.

p.#text:
This chapter is intended as a kind of counterblast to Protagoras' claim on behalf of  in ff. In general tone
as well as in many of the particular statements it is elaborately
ironical; but it should be remembered that Plato thought highly
in many respects of the Cretan and Spartan constitutions and
borrowed much from them in constructing his ideal city.

own doctrine that ill doing comes from want of knowledge.

notion and less. It would be more in conformity with experience to say that the  does become by practising

div1.head: CHAPTER XXXII
p:

himself disparagingly on poetical criticism. With some reluctance

div1.head: CHAPTER XXXIV
p:
Protagoras gives up what he had contended for before, and
contents himself with saying that courage alone is quite different
from its sister virtues. Socrates endeavours to identify courage
and knowledge in a cumbrous proof, against the validity of
which Protagoras rightly protests.

And strange to say, the sons of pleasure,
They who have revelled beyond measure
In beauty, wassail, wine and treasure,
Die calm, and calmer oft than he
Whose heritage was misery.

div1.head: CHAPTER XXXV
p:
Here Socrates, taking a fresh start, endeavours to make Protagoras assent to the doctrine that pleasure is good. Protagoras
desires to have the question examined. He allows that wherever
knowledge is present, it must rule, but this is inconsistent with
the view that one can know the better and do the worse. It is
agreed to examine this popular view, in case the inquiry should
throw light on the relation between courage and the rest of
virtue. On the ethical doctrine of this and the following chapters
see Introduction, p. xxvi.

div1.head: CHAPTER XXXVI
p:
Although pleasures are sometimes called evil and pains good,
it is in such cases their consequences which are intended to be
so called: at the time itself all pain is evil, and all pleasure good.

p.#text:
The argument proceeds by these stages: First, the meaning of
 is explained (: next, it is shown that
pleasures are called evil when they bring pain in their train or
loss of pleasure, not because they are pleasant themselves
(, and that pains are called good because they
bring pleasure in their train or escape from pain, not because
they are painful themselves (; therefore pleasure in

itself is good, and pain evil (E). The rest of the chapter
forms an introduction to the chapter which follows.

div1.head: CHAPTER XXXVII
p:
The meaning of the phrase to be overcome by pleasure is now
explained in conformity with the results of the last chapter.

p.#text:
If we substitute good for pleasure the common saying
that we do evil, knowing it to be evil, because overcome by
pleasure, becomes we do evil knowing it to be evil, because
overcome by good (C). To be overcome by good is
shown to be the choosing of greater evil in place of lesser good
(D-E). Similarly, substituting pleasure for good, and pain for
evil, we have the sentiment we do the painful, knowing it to be
painful, because overcome by pleasure, and here also to be
overcome by pleasure is to choose in place of lesser pleasures
greater pains (. No doubt in this case the pleasures
are present and the pains remote, but we make allowance for
this in our process of weighing pleasures and pains against
themselves and one another (C). Near and Far have
the same bewildering effect on the eyes when we look at size
and number; but there the arts of measurement and of arithmetic resolve our perplexity (. In like manner there
must be some art or knowledge whose function it is to settle the
value of more and less, near and far, etc., in their
application to pleasure and pain. In other words  is due to ignorance (.

2.   is due to a correction in one inferior
MS., approved by Cobet and Kroschel; BT have .
If we read , there are difficulties serious enough to
suggest an error in the reading: (1) the position of  is to say
the least most unusual: no example is quoted of  coming at
the end of a conditional clause in this way; (2) is  to be taken
with  in the usual sense () or as inferential? The
inferential meaning strikes us as somewhat far-fetched, and the
other is both inappropriate here and impossible from the
position of the particle. On the other hand  is almost necessary to the sense; without , the words 

would not correctly describe Socrates' procedure in the following discussion, in which he  use all four names. But as he
does not use them  his procedure is accurately described
by the addition of  to .

18. : not before your tribunal, but in you, i.e.
inside you, in your souls. The idea is of a conflict between the
good and evil in the soul before you do the evil.  might
have been , but the  now selects his interlocutors
as his examples. The subtle reasoning which follows may be put
thus: We do evil, knowing it to be evil, because  are overcome
by good. Butsince that which we do is evilthe good which
overcomes is less worthy than  which it overcomes.
Less worthy (to overcome) means that there is less of it: to
be overcome by good is therefore to choose less good than evil.
The argument is extraordinarily ingenious but hardly sound
the flaw lies in substituting the evil in us for us; it was not
the evil in us, but we who were overcome by good. See also
Introduction, p. xxvi. The usual way of taking  as before
your tribunal or the like (cf. ) makes the false step
much more serioussince it substitutes not the evil in us but
simply the evil for us.

Let us eat and drink; for tomorrow we die. Near and

man is immortal and will live hereafter under the same

in this dialogue.

div1.head: CHAPTER XXXVIII
p:
Socrates begins to apply the results of the previous discussion to
the subject of his dispute with Protagoras.

Pleasure is good and pain evil, and no one willingly encounters
what he believes to be evil. But fear is the expectation of evil:
therefore no one will willingly encounter what he fears.

p.#text:

its omission would be to render the address unduly abrupt.

3. . So the MSS. Sauppe's  is not necessary. 
means all three sophists: and  is not the discussion as a
whole, but the speaking, viz. in answer (cf. ). Throughout this chapter all the sophists reply: in the
next Socrates makes use of their united admissions to destroy
Protagoras alone.

div1.head: CHAPTER XL
p:
Socrates points out that while Protagoras' theory would point to
the conclusion that virtue is not teachable, he himself in trying
to prove that virtue is knowledge goes near to maintaining that
it is. Thus the interlocutors have as it were changed places. The
dialogue ends with mutual compliments.

hi.#text:
Das Gedicht des Simonides
in Platons Protagoras,

Das Simonideische Gedicht in Platons Protagoras und die
Versuche dasselbe zu reconstruiren,

note.#text:
On p. 20 of his fourth edition of the  Sauppe enumerates the discussions on the subject down to 1884. The most
important contribution since that year is  von J. Aars (Christiania, 1888). Aars's restoration has received the approval of Peppmller (in the  for 1899, pp. 174 ff.) and others; and there now
seems to be some prospect of finality in the criticism of the poem. In
his programme ( Graz, 1889) Schwenk follows Aars
in every essential point.

p.title: Protagoras,
p.#text:
The difficulties of this poem are well known, and have called
forth many pages of comment. The restoration proposed by
Schneidewin has met with most favour, and is printed in most
texts of the  not because it is thought to be certain,
but as the nearest approach to certainty of which the case admits.
It may be at once allowed that no restoration can claim to represent with certainty just what Simonides wrote in the order in
which it was written. Plato is seldom careful to make his quotations accurate, and the perverse exposition of the meaning of
this particular poem is hardly calculated to increase our confidence in his verbal accuracy here. Nevertheless, Plato is our sole
authority for the poem in question, and consequently that
restoration will be the most probable which, while it satisfies
every metrical requirement, involves the fewest changes in the
text and sequence of the poem as it stands in Plato.

p:
The words apparently quoted from the poem, as they occur in
the Bodleian manuscript, are according to Schanz as follows
(we note obvious corrections at the foot of the page).

p.#text:
There is little probability in this arrangement. Schneidewin
altogether neglects the evident metrical resemblance between
the words from  to  and
the other sections of the poem. But the obvious and indeed fatal
objection to Schneidewin's restoration is that he makes a wide
departure from the order of the words as they come in Plato,
placing the  of before the  of  That Socrates  in to  is no reason for placing these words in the last part of
the poem, any more than we should place the words  after  because
Socrates reverts to them in  A man who professes to be

giving a continuous exposition of a poem may revert to the
middle of it when he has come to the end, in order to illustrate
the sentiment with which the poem concludes, but it would be
the superfluity of naughtiness to put the end of the poem into
the middle, which is what Schneidewin makes Socrates do. If
 in were in reality the conclusion of the poem,
we ought to frame our  out of these very words, and
not from  We should then have to omit
the words , because they are not found
in E, but it is beyond question that these words are part of
Simonides' poem. It is tolerably certain that in we have but
a recapitulation of part of the argument, presented as a commentary on the concluding text , which sums up the
whole ethical teaching of the poem. This is practically admitted
by Schneidewin himself when he writes his final strophe not as
it appears in  but as it stands in D.

Bergk arranges the poem in three complete strophes. His
restoration has the merit of recognising the similarity in rhythm
between Schneidewin's epode and the other parts of the poem;
several of his emendations are also in all probability right. It
may, however, be doubted whether he does well in altogether
excluding from the poem the words  and , and he deserts the Platonic order even more
ruthlessly than Schneidewin when he places   directly after , besides that Plato
clearly indicates by the words  (,
 (, and 
(, that there is a lacuna after .

p.#text:
Blass agrees with Bergk in regarding the poem as a sequence
of strophes, but discovers four of these in place of three. In the
first strophe Blass's arrangement agrees with that of Schneidewin; in the second, he supposes the first two verses to be lost,
and the rest to contain  down to ; the third consists of ; the fourth and last extends from  to . This arrangement
(which further agrees with that of Bergk in rejecting  and ) upsets even more completely

than either of the others the sequence of the poem as it is given
by Plato, and for that reason is most unlikely to be right.

The only arrangement which faithfully adheres to the
Platonic order of citation is that of Aars, in the treatise referred
to already.

p.#text:
This restoration seems to us on the whole the most probable.
In l. 4 of strophe 2 Plato no doubt wrote  (the MSS.
reading) for , using the more common construction in defiance
of metre, just as in l. 5  after  is due to the desire to show
the sequence of thought. In ll. 6 and 7 of the same strophe
Plato omits some monosyllable after , perhaps  or  or
: Hermann's view that  of the next line should be written
in l. 6, and l. 7 be made into , is perhaps
less probable. For l. 7 we should prefer as nearer to the words of
Plato  In the third strophe we prefer
 for the reasons given in the note upon the passage on
p. 180. In the last strophe  is Bergk's emendation
for : here again Plato substitutes the commoner
idiom for the rarer and more poetic, with which we may compare Aristophanes,  694 . It
is, however, more likely that Simonides wrote , i.e. , for this idiom is
seldom found with  or : see Jebb on Sophocles,
 771. To take  for  would give a wrong
meaning, as can be seen from the paraphrase in . It seems better too, in
this line, to take  (sc. )
together, and print colons before  and after . In l. 4
 is Bergk's restoration for  of the MSS. The
position assigned by Aars to  (in l. 2) is
only tentative, but it is slightly supported by  coming before  in 
There is nothing in Plato to indicate that the first line (with part
of the second) is wanting in strophe 4, but neither is there anything to prove the reverse, and (since the poem is not in any
case preserved entire, five verses being omitted in the first
strophe) it is much more reasonable to assume an omission here
than violently to distort the sequence of the poem as quoted by
Plato.

p.title: Protagoras.
p.#text:
Whether the poem is to be ranked as an , an
, or a  is a question which should not be raised
until the poem has first been restored from the quotations in the
 If the restoration given above is even approximately
correct, the poem cannot be classed as an epinikion; an encomium it is not likely to be, since no one is praised. There is no
reason whatever for identifying it with the famous encomium

referred to by Quintilian (XI. 2. 11). Blass holds that the poem
was a scolion, and this is by far the most probable view, but no
certainty is attainable on the point. With the exception of the
lacunae which we have noted, the poem is most probably
complete, for Socrates is trying to prove that Simonides attacks
Pittacus throughout the  poem: see  and

p:
We add a translation of the poem, incorporating the few
changes which we have made in Aars's restoration.

It is hard to quit you like a truly good man, in hands and feet
and mind foursquare, fashioned without blame.

p.#text:
(The five lost  may have further elaborated the meaning of
truly good.)

p:
Nor do I deem the word of Pittacus well said, wise though he
was that spake it: it is hard he said to be noble. To a god
alone belongs that meed; a man cannot but prove evil, if hopeless calamity overthrow him. Every man if he has fared well is
good, evil, if ill; and for the most part best are they whom the
gods love.

Therefore never will I cast away my portion of life vainly upon
a bootless hope, seeking what cannot come to be, an all-blameless man, of us who take the fruit of the broad earth; when I find
him, look you, you shall hear. I praise and love all them that
willingly do nothing base; against necessity even gods do not
contend.

[I love not fault-finding]; enough for me if one be not evi
nor exceeding violent: yea sound is the man who knoweth justice,
benefactress of cities; nor will I find fault with him; for the tribe
of fools is infinite. Surely all is fair wherein is no alloy of foul.

The easy-going morality of the poem is in harmony with what
we know both of the life and poetry of Simonides: he was ever a
genial and courtly man, anxious to make the most of life,
dwelling with flowers like the bee, seeking yellow honey (Sim.
Frag. 47).
